displayed_text: Patient: ‘Cuz see, I don’t know how I got careless, and, and, but I keep a lot of stuff in my pockets. When it happened before where I was. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, I did like I said, did like I told her and she been like I told you (Miss F_ and I said) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: And call me. Let my daughter know and let me know.” ‘Cuz I’m sure I’m gonna press charges. I swear to God, I’m gonna press charges. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. So, what happened then? Did they give you the medication? Patient: Huh? Doctor: Last time, what happened? Did they give you the medicine? Patient: No, I, I, I just, the last one you gave me is the one that I lost. But I picked up the one that you gave me before then. Doctor: Before? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So, you picked it up on August thirtieth? Patient: The, no, the, I think

Patient: So I I I know you understand… Doctor: Real well. Patient: …everything that I’m saying. Doctor: Absolutely. No question. The anxiety is what the PSA is gonna be you know whether it’s gonna reoccur. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: All those things went through my mind is what’s going through yours. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So… Patient: It took you a while to get to it? Doctor: Oh yeah. Patient: You know I just ask the question. Doctor: Oh yeah well absolutely, yeah.

Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. It is one injection and then watch it? Doctor: Uh usually it’s, it’s IV, it’s every three weeks for as far as it works. So it could be you know- Patient: A year? Doctor: I don’t know what that all costs, but uh- Family Member: But do you know right away after one or two?

Patient: Pat We’re looking at potent—very, uh, plausibly potential choices down the road. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And, and, and so at this point --- Doctor: I mean, including standard of care. So, standard of care is always our baseline. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we, you know, I could just, my description will be, “here’s what standard of care does, here’s what we expect.” Patient: Well, well, I guess what I’m asking, if my PSA stays down - Doctor: The standard of care is – Patient: We should do nothing. Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level?

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay. As much as we can. Patient: Can I sign now, and-? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When do I have to sign? Doctor: Oh. You have to sign when you are feeling- when you feel comfortable. It’s just that- Patient: I feel comfortable now. I mean. Doctor: Okay. All right. Then I think you should- Patient: As long as we can work around- Doctor: Yeah. We’ll try and work around most of those dates. If, only it becomes a problem, we may have to delay it, doing your second eye or whatever. Family Member: Because it’s all, yeah. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good. Doctor: Okay what is…? Patient: I don’t have any you know… Doctor: Is this ten mg? Patient: Five in the morning, five at night. Doctor: Okay did it flare up after the treatment last time? Family Member: No.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islande: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: T_ may be able to do it all in one day. I’m not a big fan of all in one day. Uh, just because, uh, it’s got a lot of hoops, and if you don’t have it. So, tend to see you on a Tuesday. Is everything clear? And, then we pick a day and you just go and get it. Patient: Alright. Doctor: And then that day, the people upstairs have cleared it for you. Your, uh, counts are okay. That your time is upstairs is shortened because - - Patient: I won’t have to wait for results. Doctor: Correct. Patient: Now is it possible to get the pre and/or post treatments at a local or local - Healthcare Professional: The draw? Patient: LabCorp or Quest or something? Doctor: Yes, absolutely. Patient: Okay. ‘Cuz I don’t mind comin’ down obviously, but if I can shave a couple hours out of a day- Doctor: Yeah. If you on a Monday, went over to LabCorp, got your blood tests, awesome. Tuesday, we clear you, and if you want Wednesday or Thursday to be your chemo day, you just tell me.

Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Until we can go and talk about that. No rush. Plus your next shot I think is April fourth. So we may uh, you know, we’ll work on that, but you may even be, you come in at the same time, and we can use that same visit. So I’ll look at that. Okay? Any questions? Patient: I didn’t know that you - So that’s what I had? I had cancer, I mean, uh, I had pneumonia and-? Doctor: Pneumonia and the flu. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: The flu? Yeah. That’s what I had before. Doctor: Yeah. I think that’s what happened when I talked to your doctor. They were for sure about pneumonia. They were waiting on the flu results at the time. But I think they treated you like you had the flu, anyway, so. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: By the time there the next day they gave me some potassium and they gave me antibiotics. Doctor: Um hum. Um hum. Yeah. Patient: And was walking in an hour or two. Doctor: Yeah. And you were really dehydrated. Patient: Yeah I was.

Patient: I didn’t ever know. I didn’t realize, I didn’t realize this is my third year doing it, and I didn’t realize I was - Doctor: No shave, but I, I think that’s what that fundraiser is for. Patient: This is just County Sherriff’s Department. Doctor: No shave November. So, Movember, it is a big - they raise millions. Patient: No kidding. Doctor: They give, uh, grants and do a lot of support for, uh- Yeah, this is my eighth year. (softly) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: I’m going through your medicines. Still taking your Advair as needed? Patient: Right. Doctor: Your atorvastatin ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Injections into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh but that’s I don’t know if I gave you a book about that or not. Patient: Uh no, no you just you know you discussed the options. Doctor: Well I’ll get you some literature about that, but injections would be the next step. Patient: Oh no. Doctor: There’s a vacuum devise that we can use Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: and ultimately there’s a penile prosthesis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: That we can give and we have a person here now who specializes in sexual function.
